author: Staff Reporter
text:
State-level struggle committee to meet on Saturday to decide on the next step

Primary school teachers joined the protests to air their demands in Vellore on Thrusday.— Photo: C. Venkatachalapathy

Government employees intensified their protests on Thursday by launching a relay protest in front of the Collector’s office.

S. Venkatachalam, district secretary of Tamil Nadu Government All Department Employees Associations’ Struggle Committee said nearly 1,300 employees participated in the protest from morning, and they decided to restrict the number to 150 to stay back for the night at the protest venue.

“We expected an announcement from the government today. A team led by R. Thamizhselvi, president of Tamil Nadu Government Employees Association is visiting six districts, including Vellore, to look at the situation. The State-level struggle committee will meet on Saturday to decide the next round of protests,” he said.

Meanwhile, primary school teachers have also been participating in the protest since February 15. Apart from the demand to scrap the Contributory Pension Scheme, the teachers are demanding salary on par with Central Government teachers and filling up of vacancies.

“There is a difference of about Rs. 6,000 in the salary between a Central Government and State Government teacher. A secondary grade teacher in Tamil Nadu receives a grade pay of Rs. 2,800, while their counterpart in a Central Government school gets Rs. 4,200,” K. Saravanaraj, district convenor of the struggle committee said. They are also demanding the scrapping of consolidate pay, honorarium and outsourcing, and following only time scale pay for all employees, he added.
title: Govt. employees launch a relay protest in Vellore
